repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Road Rehabilitation and
            Maintenance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Road Rehabilitation and Maintenance
            Project in Bangladesh. The objectives of the project were
            to: (a) reduce transport costs of passengers and goods, in
            particular for food products, by restoring the most
            important major trunk roads in northwestern parts of
            Bangladesh to maintainable condition; (b) introduce
            institutional and technical improvements in the programming
            of works, the administration and maintenance of the road
            system and in technical standards and materials; and (c)
            upgrade the capabilities of the local contracting industry
            to undertake larger road works as an alternative to
            inefficient and very small size contracts. The project was
            successful in achieving its principal objectives. The key
            lessons learned from the project are as follows: 1) An
            efficient and effective maintenance management system needs
            to be in place to ensure sustainability of road
            improvements; 2) To ensure the integrity of road networks,
            the issue of vehicle overloading and axle load control is an
            issue of major concern. This needs coordinated efforts from
            all concerned agencies in both the public and private
            sectors; 3) With roads improved under the project, the speed
            of the vehicles has increased and so correspondingly has the
            number and severity of road accidents and fatalities on some
            inter urban sections of the project roads due to lack of
            enforcement; 4) There is also a need to streamline the
            procurement processing of GOB for the award of both
            consultancy and construction contracts, which on many
            occasions has caused long delays in awarding of the
            contracts; 5) Supply of bitumen from the Government
            refineries was often inadequate; 6) The cumbersome
            bureaucratic procedures for custom clearance to import
            materials and construction equipment into the country cause
            tremendous delays and heavy losses for both the local and
            foreign construction companies based in Bangladesh; and 7)
            To ensure full benefits of the training sub-component under
            the institutional development components, it is important to
            develop a comprehensive training program in close
            consultation with the borrowers.

Bangladesh - Road Rehabilitation

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Road Rehabilitation and
            Maintenance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
With the Road Rehabilitation and
            Maintenance Project, the country hopes to ameliorate its
            inadequate road network which is now in need of an
            integrated program for construction, modernization,
            rehabilitation maintenance, to meet the burgeoning demand
            for road transport.  To this end, the project specifically
            includes civil works and an institutional development
            program.  The first component of civil works comprises (i)
            road rehabilitation; (ii) deferred maintenance works; and
            (iii) supervision.  In line with this, the institutional
            development program comprises:  (i) preparation of a Road
            Master Plan; (ii) implementation of an action plan for
            improved road maintenance; and (iii) implementation of an
            action plan to strengthen the construction industry.
